facts.text: Appeal filed as Civil Appeal No. 65 of 1957 from Punjab High Court judgment dated January 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 65 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 1, 1956, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 28 of 1955

facts.text: Certificate of fitness granted by Punjab High Court on August 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed with a certificate of fitness granted by the Punjab High companyrt on August 20. 1956. It is directed against the judgment and order passed by a Division Bench of that companyrt on January 19, 1956

facts.text: Single Judge Mr. Justice Harnam Singh allowed Civil Writ No. 36-D of 1955 on April 15, 1955, setting aside reversion order of August 19, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: reversing the judgment and order of Mr. Justice Harnam Singh pronounced on April 15, 1955, whereby his Lordship had allowed the appellants application being Civil Writ No. 36-D of 1955 and set aside the order passed by the General Manager, Northern Railway on August 19, 1953

facts.text: Appellant joined railway service as Signaller Telegraphist in August 1924.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are shortly as follows-In August 1924 the appellant joined the railway service as a Signaller  Telegraphist . As a result of selection, he was promoted as Section Controller in 1942

facts.text: Appellant promoted to Section Controller in 1942, Deputy Chief Controller in 1947, Chief Controller in 1950, all in Class III service.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of selection, he was promoted as Section Controller in 1942 and as Deputy Chief Controller in 1947 and as the Chief Controller in 1950. All these posts were in Class III service.

facts.text: On March 31, 1951, appellant selected by selection board for post of Assistant Superintendent Railway Telegraphs, Class II.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1951, seven candidates, including the appellant, appeared before a selection board companystituted for selecting a candidate for the post of Assistant Superintendent Railway Telegraphs, which was a gazetted post in Class 11 Officers cadre.

facts.text: Appointment notice issued July 2, 1951, to officiate as Asst. Spdt. Rly. Telegraphs, Class II.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1951, a numberice of appointment was issued from the headquarters of the East Punjab Railway, Delhi, numberifying that Mr. Parshotam Lal, Officiating Chief Controller, is appointed to officiate in Class II service as Asstt. Spdt. Rly. Telegraphs

facts.text: Appellant relieved Mr. Sahu Ram on afternoon of July 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The applicant actually relieved Mr. Sahu Ram in the afternoon of July 3, 1951.

facts.text: Adverse remarks made by Gouri Shankar S.T.E.I. on April 28, 1953, in confidential report for year ending March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on April 28, 1953, one Gouri Shankar S.T.E.I. Hd. Qrs. made certain adverse remarks against the appellant in his companyfidential report for the year ending March 31, 1953.

facts.text: Shri Sen, C.S.T.E., confirmed adverse views on May 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: This companyfidential report came before Shri Sen, C.S.T.E., on May 25,1953, who companyfirmed the views expressed by Shri Gouri Shankar and added his own opinion which was also adverse to the appellant.

facts.text: General Manager Shri Karnail Singh remarked on June 11, 1953, expressing disappointment and suggesting reversion.

anchor.surface_text: According to the usual practice obtaining in the office the aforesaid remarks were placed before the General Manager, Shri Karnail Singh, who on June 11, 1953, remarked thereon as follows I am disappointed to read these reports.

facts.text: Adverse remarks communicated to appellant by confidential letter dated June 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The adverse remarks against the appellant in the companyfidential report for the year ending March 31, 1953, which were companymunicated to the appellant for his information by a companyfidential letter No. E-106/180 dated June 29, 1953

facts.text: Appellant made representation against remarks on July 24, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On July 24, 1953, the appellant, who had by this time earned two increments on July 4, 1952 and July 4, 1953, made a representation against the remarks made against him.

facts.text: General Manager issued notice No. 940-E/14 E.I.A. on August 19, 1953, reverting appellant to Class III post.

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, 1953, however, numberice No. 940-E/14  E.I.A.  was issued by the General Manager  P  to the following effect Shri Bishambar Nath Chopra, Instructor Railway Training School, Saharnpur, is transferred to Headquarters office and appointed to officiate in Class 11 service as Assistant Signal and Tele-communication Engineer  Telegraphs  vice Shri Parshotam Lal Dhingra

facts.text: Appellant appealed to General Manager on August 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on August 20, 1953, appealed to the General Manager for reconsideration and thereafter on October 19, 1953, appealed to the Railway Board and made a representation also to the President of India.

facts.text: Railway Board wrote to General Manager on February 2, 1955, upholding reversion but not barring future promotion.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1955, the Railway Board wrote to the General Manager as follows With reference to your letter No. 3780 dated the 30th December, 1953, the Board desires that you should inform Shri Parshotam Lal Dhingra that his reversion for generally unsatisfactory work will stand

facts.text: Petitioner filed writ petition under Art. 226 on February 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime the petitioner had on February 9, 1955, filed his writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Division Bench (Bhandari C.J. and Falshaw J.) reversed Single Judge on January 19, 1956, dismissing writ.

anchor.surface_text: On a Letters Patent Appeal filed by the Union of India, a Division Bench  Bhandari C. J. and Falshaw J.  reversed the order of Harnam Singh J. and dismissed the petitioners writ application.

facts.text: Supreme Court held reversion order of August 19, 1953, not a reduction in rank under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances there is numberescape from the companyclusion that the petitioner was number reduced in rank by way of punishment and, therefore, the provisions of Art. 311  2  do number companye into play at all.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court with costs.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.

under Art. 226 of the Constitution. Mr. Justice Harnam Singh took the view that the petitioner had been punished by being reduced in rank without being given an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him and that consequently the order was invalid for non-compliance with the provisions of Art. 311 ( 2 ) of the Constitution.

issues.text: This appeal raises a very important question about the construction of art. 311 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Petitioner appointed on officiating basis with no right to continue in post and reversion entailed no forfeiture of chances of future promotion or seniority

arguments.claim: Art. 311 protections apply to all government servants without distinction between permanent and temporary or officiating

anchor.surface_text: Article 311 does number, in terms, say that the protections of that article extend only to persons who are permanent members of the services or who hold permanent civil posts. To limit the operation of the protective provisions of this article to these classes of persons will be to add qualifying words to the article which will be contrary to sound principles of interpretation of a Constitution or a statute.

arguments.claim: Precedents holding Art. 311 limited to permanent servants are incorrect as contrary to plain text

anchor.surface_text: A number of decisions bearing on the question of construction of Arts. 310 and 311 have been cited before us which indicate that there is some difference of opinion... Thus it has been held in some cases that Arts. 310 and 311 do number make any distinction between Government servants who are employed in permanent posts and those who are employed in temporary posts.

arguments.claim: Reversion based on unsatisfactory work but without barring future promotion is not punitive

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1955, the Railway Board wrote to the General Manager... his reversion for generally unsatisfactory work will stand, but that this reversion will number be a bar to his being considered again for a promotion in the future if his work and conduct justify.

arguments.court_reasoning: No forfeiture of future chances confirmed

holdings.text: The order passed by the General Manager on August 19, 1953, did not amount to a reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles discussed above it is quite clear that the petitioner before us was appointed to the higher post on an officiating basis... He had no right to continue in that post... Nor did this reduction... entail the forfeiture of his chances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner appointed on officiating basis with no substantive right to post; reversion to substantive Class III post entailed no forfeiture of seniority or future promotion chances.

holdings.text: Art. 311 makes no distinction between permanent and temporary members of services or holders of permanent or temporary posts; protections extend to all such government servants.

anchor.surface_text: Article 311 does not, in terms, say that the protections of that article extend only to persons who are permanent members of the services or who hold permanent civil posts. To limit the operation of the protective provisions of this article to these classes of persons will be to add qualifying words to the article which will be contrary to sound principles of interpretation of a Constitution or a statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Arts. 310-311; no qualifying words limiting to permanents; all classes require protection equally.

holdings.text: Termination of service is by way of punishment attracting Art. 311(2) only if the servant had a right to the post or the order entails penal consequences such as loss of seniority, pay, or promotion prospects.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from service rules history, where dismissal/removal/reduction denote major punishments; applied to constitutional words; distinguishes contractual termination from punitive.

holdings.text: The words 'dismissed', 'removed', 'reduced in rank' in Art. 311 denote the three major punishments from service rules requiring procedural safeguards.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 49, as originally framed, provided as follows The following penalties may, for good and sufficient reason and as hereinafter provided, be imposed upon members of the services... dismissal from the Civil Service of the Crown, which, ordinarily disqualifies from future employment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evolution from 1915/1935 Acts and service rules (Classification Rules, Railway Code) where these are graver penalties with special procedure, incorporated into Constitution.

holdings.text: Termination of officiating appointment per service rules does not amount to punishment, dismissal, removal, or reduction in rank.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1702 of Chapter XVII prescribes eleven distinct penalties... Note below this rule to the effect that the discharge (a) of a person appointed on probation... (c) of a person appointed in a temporary capacity otherwise than under a contract... do not amount to removal or dismissal within the meaning of r. 1702.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit notes/explanations in Railway Code r.1702 and CCS Rules r.49 confirm such discharges not punishment.

holdings.text: Art. 310 adopts pleasure doctrine subject to express qualifications in Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: Article 310 (1) and Art. 311 omitting the proviso to cl. (2) are as follows 310 (1) Except as expressly provided by this Constitution, every person who is a member of a defence service or of a civil service of the Union or of an all-India Service or holds any post connected with defence or any civil post under the Union,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Traces from English common law through 1915/1935 Acts to Constitution; 311 as proviso to 310.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must, therefore, be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reversion valid, no violation of Art. 311(2).
